I didn't expect much when I picked that game up. I actually saw this game lying on the Steam Store shelf for a crazy 0,36 euros, so I had to check it out. Imagine Portal without portals and humor. It's the most basic 3D puzzle game you can imagine. It's not as boring as it sounds. It's super-short, for one thing. It's not a game you pick-up and replay over and over again. It's one of those ' I've got nothing to play ' kinda game. Everything seems alright, but after diging in I've found some flaws. Controller support is clunky and it doesn't always work. The menus are glitchy unless you disable the gamepad in the settings. For most people this game would probably bore you to death, but not me. I've sat through this thing and I actually found some impressive puzzles. For a game all about picking up things and throwing them, that's quire an accomplishment. I launched Vs mode just out of morbid curiosity. My brother just died in front of the monitor. It's not a fun multiplayer game to play. The rules are easy and there's no challenge. Combine that with gamepad controls and you've got yourself a nice nightmare session.  The best thing about this game is the soundtrack.  Spectrosconomy  is probably the best track on the whole game. It's in the trailer and it deserves some recognition on SoundCloud. Go look it up and show Ludiotic some love.  For the full price, avoid immediately. Wait for a crazy sale to make this game pay-off. It's not a novelty, but I think I could let this game pass.

I would recommend this game on sale or in a bundle. The puzzles are interesting, although fairly easy. I was able to 100% this game in just under 4 hours. Pros:      Interesting puzzles   Appealing visuals   Should run on almost any PC   Occasionally clever level design   New mechanics are introduced organically, so it is very easy to learn how they work by just experimenting    Cons:     While visuals are pleasant, they are very rudimentary and this could detract from some people's experience   Almost no plot at all   Co-op is split-screen only   Very short playthrough   I found it too easy to blow through each level, and most data nodes (3 collectables in each level) aren't really hidden at all   The cons I have listed, while obviously negative points, don't really detract from my overall opinion of the game. I enjoyed it, and considering the cost of the game I felt like the investment was worth it. With so many games pushing 80+ hours to complete these days, it was refreshing to spend a buck for a few hours of entertainment.

This game is SHORT, but it's a lot of fun. It's in the vein of Portal but without anything but the mere hint of a story. You are a 'hacker' who, instead of using computers at all, uses colored light and switches to achieve your aims, collecting 'data fragments' that are just collectibles scattered throughout the level. This thin excuse for a story aside, it's got good mechanics. You can reverse your polarity to either red or blue to pass through lasers and forcefields, or have your polarity opposite so you can walk across light bridges. There are a lot of putting-cubes-on-switches and jumping through forcefields while changing your polarity midair, and it gets pretty easy near the end once you've gotten the hang of it. It feels like I just finished the tutorial level and am waiting for the bigger levels.  8/10 overall, mostly for game length. You should definitely buy this, but don't pay more than $5 or you'll feel ripped off.

This makes some levels a bit frustrating. -EXTREMELY easy game - even the most 'challenging' levels only take a couple minutes to finish. Several of the data (the things you collect each level) are in plain sight or hidden in painfully obvious hiding places. There is little to no challange in the puzzles.   Overall, I thought the game was enjoyable but definately not worth $11. I did not play the coop or vs modes, so perhaps these modes give some extra worth. I bought it on sale so it was dirt cheap. 1 Line review: It's like Portal, but without Portals. Also, it's very short. 5/10  Full Review: There isn't much to talk about this. The story is almost non-existent and is just a bunch (~20 + 10 extras) of really short levels (5min max if you want to get everything in each level). I'd say that the concept is kinda cool: instead of Portals, you have you manipulate your own 'polarity', between red or blue if you don't want to die from lasers of that color, if you want to be above platforms of those colors and even transport cubes of those colors without desintegrating them.  As a puzzle game, I didn't find it hard, only slightly on very specific segments that you have to get some items to unlock the ending. It should be more as an introdutory puzzle game to kids ages 8 and lower rather than to teens and adults used to more complex games like The Talos Principle and PQ (the psp exclusive). If you fall on the latter category, this game should be just one or two hours long.  On the other hand, this game often comes *really* cheap, like dirt cheap (some 50 cents... no pun intended), so the price/game hours ratio isn't that bad. The experience itself is bug-free and the visual is simple and a little retro, so it's nice to relax if you want something for that. Visuals are quite simple as well, but don't strain the eyes.  Overall, it is a fair game... I mean, fairly standard. Short, cheap, soothing, but nothing more. Well, it has multiplayer, but it's not that entertaining as other puzzle multiplayer games. So, just don't expect much.

This game... I don't know where to begin. It can be a fun timekiller for a little while, but it's never worth the full asking price of 9,99€. It's on sale right now for 0,99€, and I think that should be the normal price, because clearly there didn't go a lot of work into making the game.  I guess the devs went for a clean and minimalist look, like Portal or Q.U.B.E, and I guess it's ok, but it looks rather dull and like something that everyone could piece together in some game construction kit within a couple of minutes.  All the puzzles are very easy, and not very well designed. If you have ever played user made puzzles for Portal 2, you probably know what I mean. They work, and you had to think a bit about how to solve it, but all in all they seem designed quite badly, compared to the dev-made puzzles. Alle the levels in this game feel the same.  Most of them don't even use that Polarity concept all that much. It's more about taking a blue or red cube to a receptacle of the same colour and activate something that helps you through the level (platform, acceleration ramp, opening a gate etc.). Sometimes you have to throw the cubes at the receptacles, which works reasonably well.  The controls are fine, though the air controls seem a bit off.  The main reason why I think this is worth more like 1€ than 10€ is that the main game consists of 11 (extremely short and easy) levels. There are also 10 bonus levels and a coop campaign, but... come on, really? At about level 8 there suddenly is this new mechanic where you can change the colour of your cube by throwing it through a green force field. This mechanic isn't introduced in any way, and the only reason it's still quite easy to figure out by yourself is because the level design is so bleak that there aren't to much possibilities. It's like 'ok, here's this red cube, there's a blue receptacle, and there is nothing else in this room except that green force field over there', so your options are so limited that you soon arrive at the correct solution.  Oh, what I didn't mention so far: you also have to collect 3 green glowing things (aka 'Datasets') in every room for no apparent reason. Yes, the story tells you why, but they just feel like this arbitrary thing you also have to do that has nothing to do with solving the room's puzzles. Sometimes they're hidden, but that doesn't really work either, because of the empty level design. If you are at the end of the level and you're missing one of them, it's just like 'well, then I'll have to go over there where it's probably hidden and where I didn't go before because I had absolutely no reason to'.  TL;DR: Puzzles too easy, just 11 levels in the main campaign, bad level design. It's like the easy first few puzzles of other puzzle games, in length as well as in difficulty.  I wouldn't recommend buying this even at 0,99€ unless you also have someone to play the coop campaign with. I got mine for free, if you can get it free, go for it. It can be entertaining for a short while.

Nothing game breaking though.  Unfortunately I don’t have any friends with this game, so I can’t say anything about the co-op side of it. Overall it’s an okay game, it’s just not one I’ll be recommending to people unless they want a really simple and short puzzler.
